Yesterday, in his speech at the Democratic National Convention, John Kerry explained his views on religion's place in a president's life. urlLink And let me say it plainly: in that cause, and in this campaign, we welcome people of faith. America is not us and them. I think of what Ron Reagan said of his father a few weeks ago, and I want to say this to you tonight: I don't wear my own faith on my sleeve. But faith has given me values and hope to live by, from Vietnam to this day, from Sunday to Sunday. I don't want to claim that God is on our side. As Abraham Lincoln told us, I want to pray humbly that we are on God's side. And whatever our faith, one belief should bind us all: The measure of our character is our willingness to give of ourselves for others and for our country. I would like to comment on this. If America is "not us and them," then why does he differentiate between people who "wear [their] faith on their sleeve" and people who just "welcome people of faith." If he really meant that, he wouldn't even mention the thing about wearing religion on one's sleeve; he'd just paraphrase something Bush said about religion, say he agrees, and explain how it applies to his life, like what he said about Abraham Lincoln. I actually agree with what he said about Lincoln but I doubt he meant it the way Lincoln intended it to mean. Kerry probably believes God is for politically-correctness and against the Biblical view of morality. Lincoln was probably more in favor of the Biblical view. Jimmy

With computer software, new isn't always better. Why waste money on the newest versions of software when the old versions will do everything you need them to do. I still use Wordperfect 8 (from 1997) for grammar-checking French and I just bought Virtual PC on eBay (haven't received it yet) for $ with the shipping. I'm sure I won't miss any of the features on the new version with would've cost me $109 plus S/H. Also, pay software isn't always better. I use tons of freeware available for free on the net. Why pay $1000 for Adobe Photoshop when the urlLink GIMP is free. Not only does it share many of Photoshop's features (including things only added in later versions, such as the pen tool), it also works just like Photoshop. urlLink OpenOffice.org is a great office suite that reads and writes MS Office file formats. urlLink Grisoft provides an anti-virus program to home users free of charge. urlLink RAD Game Tools offers a free download to permit the conversion of Quicktime videos into other formats. You won't need to pay the $30 for Quicktime Pro. There are urlLink alternative Quicktime and Real Player codecs available which allow you to read and convert Quicktime and Real media files. The Quicktime Alternative and Real Alternative codecs don't restrict you to proprietary software. You'll be able to play Quicktime and Real media files in your favorite media player. Note: Real Alternative's presence on your computer will prevent Real Player from launching at all. You may need to change the file extension to .avi for your favorite programs to play Real media files. I have no experience with Quicktime Alternative. I use other free titles but those have been the solutions to many of my problems. Jimmy

For example, many people who download pirated music have entitlement mentality. They refuse to accept that people's (blue-collar workers) livlihood may depend on earning money from said music. They refuse to accept that people's careers may depend on it. They refuse to accept that the music is worth anything. If you even so much as criticize them, they get defensive and start to talk as if you're trying to take away their liberty. One common argument they use to defend themselves is that everyone does it, even the person who's criticizing them. I read somewhere that even at the hight of downloading, the figure of people who download pirated music was only 21%. (I'm really sorry but I don't have a source for this.) The point is that they're so self-centered that they can't fathom that anyone would behave differently from them. They also argue that the prices are exhorbitant. I've demonstrated that I do know how to translate (although I admit that I don't know any Biblical languages). However, translation from French to English is not completely unlike translating from Hebrew, Aramaic, or Greek into English. There's always the same quandery, "Should I keep this like how it looks in X language, should I make it look like something one would say in English, or should I do something in-between." French-speaking people often say "to have a right" when English-speaking people would use "to be able, can." For example, "Click here to have a right to see the new photo of..." (I think that may have to do with entitlement mentality, but that's another topic.) It looks strange to right that in English but it's normal in French. Nevertheless, to avoid fornication, let every man have his own wife, and let every woman have her own husband." The KJV's "wife" and "husband" become "regular partner" in the "Good as New." It's very easy to explain why this is a miss-translation. "Wife" and "husband" suggest a marriage ceremony. "Regular urlLink partner " suggests a girlfriend/boyfriend where marriage hasn't necessary taken place. This ignores all the verses in the old testament that give urlLink wife and urlLink husband clear definitions. Jimmy
